question_text: Derive the expression for particle turbulent diffusivity in the strong-drift limit and explain how eddy-crossing time and continuity effects lead to anisotropic diffusion.
standard_answer: In the strong-drift limit (γ >> 1), particle motion dominates over turbulence, leading to frozen turbulence approximation. The eddy-crossing time scales are τsd,x = Λx/〈w〉 and τsd,y = Λy/〈w〉, derived from spatial correlations along the particle path. Diffusivity components become Θsd,x = τsd,x uΛ^2 = (Λx/〈w〉) uΛ^2 and Θsd,y = τsd,y uΛ^2 = (Λy/〈w〉) uΛ^2. Anisotropy arises from continuity effects in homogeneous isotropic turbulence, where Λy = Λz = (1/2)Λx due to mass conservation constraints on velocity fluctuations. Thus, lateral diffusivity is half the streamwise value: Θsd,y = (1/2)Θsd,x. This anisotropy means particles diffuse faster along the mean relative velocity direction, forming ellipsoidal clouds. The physical basis is that lateral velocity fluctuations are constrained by continuity, reducing correlation lengths and timescales perpendicular to the drift, intensifying directional dependence in dispersion.
